title: Fix to door closing mechanism for Panasonic Microwave model NN-ST780S
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Fix for issue with door closing mechanism on Panasonic microwave model NN-ST780S. I have had issues with this microwave for a while now where it doesn't recognise that the door is shut. I have created 2 parts (which I have printed in ABS) to slot in-between the plastic door closing frame and the metal fame of the microwave (see videos below... the parts where printed in white).

Before video: https://youtu.be/NzVg8lWqr7w
After video: https://youtu.be/RAS0p6jsj7g

I used glue and replaced the screws in the plastic door frame with longer ones so that they would reach into the printed parts.

description.text: Cherry MX Keycaps

My version of modified x-carriage to solve the problem of the belt rubbing reported by owners, myself included.
The transparent part shows the part that I have raised (4mm) to allow for belt adjustment.

comments.text: Has this solved anyone's problem of the belt rubbing?  I've seen many types of changes like this, but not seen many comments stating that it solved the issue.
comments.author: sblaske

comments.text: In my setup, yes. I have used my printer for several thousand hours without any issues. This is not a "fix all" mod, but it will give you extra couple of mm to mount belt toward the rear. Think of the setup as triangle, you have left GT2 pulley, right x-end idler and the two belt mount pints. By installing the belt ends further back (that is the key, do not push the belt all the way in toward the front when you install the belt), as it moves, it will pull the belt toward the rear thus preventing it from rubbing.

title: TSB-2555BXZ3 Side-Address Shock Isolated Saddle for BM-700 / BM-800

description.text:
This is a combination saddle and post for mounting a Transound TSB-2555BXZ3 capsule in a generic Chinese microphone body (BM-700 / BM-800) for side-address use. It should print fine without additional support on most printers.

The mounting holes should match the holes in any of the BM-700 and BM-800 derivative microphones. The one caveat is that some of these microphones only have two of the four holes tapped in their upper plates. The holes are tapped to take M2.5 screws. This will work with only two screws, but if you decide to fully populate the mounting screws, be aware you may need to purchase a tap and tap handle in order to finish the job.

The mounting holes are designed to take shock isolating grommets used for RC servos. Du-Bro #115 "Natural Rubber Grommets for Small Servos" or equivalent work fine.

The stock screws that come with the donor mic will likely be too short to use with this mount because of the additional thickness of the grommets. I used M2.5x6mm screws with M2.5 washers to mount mine. This is the shortest screw I would consider.

For this mount, the wires run down a hole through the middle of the post. The hole is 3mm in diameter, so there's not a lot of room for wires. But you shouldn't need more than 3mm to get the job done. Neumann uses the equivalent of 30ga wire on their mics. I used 28ga and still had room to wiggle. The thinner and floppier the wire, the less microphonic coupling you'll get through the capsule wires.

Attach the capsule to the saddle using an adhesive like E6000.

This, like my other capsule posts/saddles is a labor of love for the mic building community. It's an effort to make the mechanical aspects of building microphones more approachable for those without full-blown machine shops at their disposal.

This was designed in Rhino3D using a model of the BM-700 / BM-800 microphone I reverse-engineered the first time I used one as a donor body for a DIY microphone.

print_settings.Notes:: TIP THE DESIGNER

title: Dungeon Master Screen
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Dungeon Master Game Screen with two dice towers, initiative tracker, dice shelves, and dry erase marker holders! AND MORE TO COME!!! Although I wouldn't consider this a work in progress, I am actively creating more things to make it better. If you can think of how it could be better, please let me know! Follow me to be notified when I make updates for this thing!

What you need:

The screen uses 8 1/4 X 1/8 magnets in order to hold the towers to the walls. This makes each wall interchangeable! I got my magnets from Michaels, found here:
http://www.michaels.com/promag-neodymium-magnets/10413548.html

A DM Screen printout (these are suggested by the awesome Matthew Colville)
https://imgur.com/a/IXjjg
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0Byr-i7lu1I5IaW1kSWNENWdyNHc/view
http://mojobob.com/roleplay/dnd5e/Fitz's%205e%20DM%20Screen.pdf
https://drive.google.com/drive/u/0/folders/0B2EITM0tspCEc05veURKU0Q0a0U
https://olddungeonmaster.files.wordpress.com/2015/08/rrh_dm_screen_rev1.pdf

I set out to design this after being inspired by MagicEngineer's DM screen found here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2063383
However, I didn't want to use that much filament for a dm screen, so I designed it using a filament usage calculator every step of the way and got this dm screen to come in at about 888 grams! So for about $20 USD, you can have a plastic DM screen!

Printer:

TRONXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Infill:

5%

Notes:

If you set the infill to 5% or less for each part, it will take less than 1kg to print (about 888 grams in my calculations)

CALIBRATE YOUR PRINTER:

Before printing, it is vital that you have your printer calibrated. My printer wasn't when I printed a first tower, and it was a big hassle to sand the inside and outside of the tower. I calibrated my printer using the following videos and after, my second tower came out with absolutely no sanding needed.

Extrusion Rate Calibration Video:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=a1vH3ge-V3Q
Retraction Rate Calibration Video:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=wfF7-MTzlLY

TIP THE DESIGNER

If you only give once a month, please think of me next time. :)

description.text:
For whatever reason Makerbot/Thingiverse doesn't even bother to let me contest whatever a$$ decided to slap a copyright infringement on what is absolutely my own work. Since I can't upload files to it anymore, feel free to grab it from TinkerCAD and make your own STL file.
https://www.tinkercad.com/things/8fOlnP76KMs

I like still using the orginal player mat (I love the colors), so needed something that fit over top. I also wanted the organizer to stay centered on the board. author: Nataku

description.text:
This is the semi-official model of the $5 Bits of Broken Chair Trophy, shared between the football teams of the University of Minnesota and the University of Nebraska. The history behind this trophy can be found at www.brokenchairtrophy.com. Changes and updated files may be added, but the trophy is assemble-able as given.

If printing parts seperately, this print requires some assembly. If printing either the full trophy model or the "Seat and Front Legs" portion, supports are necessary.

Print above is ~2.25" W by ~1.5" D by ~2" H. Larger print sizes will better show the text on the base and the Top Right pieces.

The model was designed in Fusion 360 and the test print was created on a Wanhao Duplicator i3 at .25mm layer height with a .4mm nozzle in SainSmart woodfill filament.

A full-size model (so you can re-scale as desired) and a 1/5th scale model of the California Job Case that typesetters used to use a lot more than nowadays for movable type.

You will likely want to scale this down, or just use the 1/5th scale STL, as the full-size file is 817.5625mm x 422.275mm x 36.5125mm (32.1875" x 16.625" x 1.4375").

The file CalJobCase5thScale.stl is at 1/5 scale, and is 163.51mm x 84.46mm x 7.3mm. The photo of the type case in my hand is a 1/5th scale print in PLA.

Be careful not to scale down so far that you lose the bottom thickness in your slicer. Using a 0.2mm layer thickness yields 3 bottom layers when scaled to 1/5th.

This is a holder for my Asus PadFone. It slips into the cd slot of my car and places the PadFone on a readable airconditioned spot in front of my central heating/cooling ducts. I made it for a Peugeot 307sw (2006 model) but I would imagine that with a bit of tinkering it would fit other cars. The hole in the design fits my car kits usb plug to charge the PadFone

The file is a google SketchUp file. Just tweak, export and print it on a 3d printer. .stl available for Cura and Ultimaker. Please comment or share if you improve the design. The flat part goes into the slot of a cd player, the sides hold the PadFone.
I'll propably have to print it again and tweak the 3d printer a bit because the sides did not come out good. But it works, so it'll probabbly stay on a little while as a prototype.

5:1 size
scale it up

I wanted to lower the noise of my printer and thought it could be a good idea to make a washer from flexfilament to reduce the noise.
Why a washer? Because if you use a standard damper, the vibrations are going over the whole surface of the stepper into the printer.
With the washer, only a small surface touching the printer. So i was hoping to reduce the noise and it function.
I can say that 50% of the vibration is reduced after using the washers.
On the first picture you can see the space between stepper and printer.
Maybe you have to adjust little your pulley.

I have a Prusa MK2 and for the X-Axis Stepper, i used the 3mm washer, for the Y-Axis the 2mm.

Printtemp was 205 first layer, second 200. Heatbed = 0, infill 20%

title: Multi Color Spindown 10 Sided Die - d10 d100 d%

description.text:
As an update to my previous spindown d10 dice, I've made a two-color version. The two-color version really pops if you have some good colors, and you should even be able to match your favorite dice if you have the right colors.

I mainly use these to track numbers during games, and having them in a spindown order makes it much quicker to tick them up or down by just a couple of points at a time.

There are two sets--one with zero as the lowest number, and one with it at the highest. Use whichever you prefer, or mix and match depending on your intended use.

author: bushka

description.text:
Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:340321

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=340321

Using the following options:

BlockWidth = 2
BlockLength = 4
Name = WENDY

I wanted to upload this project to show the various processes that can be paired with 3-d printing technologies to create a DIY factory for higher volume home manufacturing. Ultimately the final part isn't very complex but i have used similar processes for other more technical projects.
A friend asked me to make small plastic toys of his company logo to use as promotional items. I ran through the possible processes to do it, the volume needed was too high to use just a 3-d printing solution and too small to justify the cost of traditional manufacturing.

I started by creating a 3-d file of the logo in solidworks and then printed some parts for size and scaling reference.
Once we had the scale decided i used a high res 3-d printer to print a test mold which was a simple negative cavity made from the original 3-d file. I used this just to prove the process and make sure the geometry of the part wouldn't cause any casting problems and to check that the final cast part would be durable enough.
Then i used a small desktop roland mdx-20 mill to cut a wax positive to cast a mold from. the file for this was just an assembly of multiple original parts laid out on a uniform ground plane. When the cut job was finished i moved the positive over to a small manual mill to clean up some edges. I added some plexi to the sides to box in the part for casting. I ended up pulling multiple molds from that original positive so i could cast dozens of parts at once.
I used smooth-on oomoo silicone to make the molds since the part was so simple and this particular silicone is incredibly easy to use. the final parts were cast with smooth-on smooth cast  and compatible pigments.
The molds were simple one sided slop molds i measured out the amount of resin i would need to fill all the molds and then added about 1/4 cup extra.
I added extra so any bubbles in the mixture would rise out of the mold in to the overflow above the top edge of the casting. I then ran a squeegee over the top of the overflowing molds and forced all the excess in to channels that i designed in to the mold. You could just push the excess over the edge of the mold but i like to make a slight attempt to keep my work area clean.
the resin set up in a few minutes and the parts pop out like an ice-cube tray.

Pros:

  • Compatible with 3x jungle mags! (or 2x placed side-to-side)
  • Retention tabs fit without any cuts/trimming work.
  • Fits 1000mAh 3s lipo.1300mAh requires a bit of cramming or dremeling.
  • Does not obstruct the side of the blaster as much where the magwell is.

Cons:

  • Retention tabs are super-thin.
  • The tab that holds the screw is also quite thin; I had to make it so in order to accommodate the jungle mags I use.
  • The screw hole is a bit too tight for M2, but that ensures the screw stays in. (I would run a drill bit through it but may increase the diameter slightly in a future revision.)
  • Additional adjustments/dremeling required to fit 1300mAh with more breathing room. (It technically still works without this, but I'm uncomfortable compressing things so much.)
  • Kind of ugly.

Designed by Louis Melgarejo

I was going to just update my old rail design as I moved forward, but frankly, this has changed too much to just serve as a simple update. If anyone's been testing the old design, and actually made anything around it, this carriage should work with the old rails, the new rails should work with the old carriages, and vice-versa. However, I don't think either were ever popular enough for that to matter much. Anyway, I've included some actual CAD files this time around as well as just simple STLs, to make it easier to integrate into your own designs. If you have a specific filetype you need, just let me know.

The rail can be scaled horizontally to whatever length you'd like, and the hexagonal hole accommodates M8 nuts perfectly. Run them along the interior to line it with an M8 threaded rod in order to mount it on other components. Similarly, the carriage operates with six M8 nuts, three M8 screws, one M3 nut, one M3 screw, and three 608 bearings. Simply attach the bearings to the screws, tighten a nut onto the screws over the bearings to act as a spacer, then screw those into the carriage, putting three M8 nuts into the slots provided. Adding an M3 screw to the top and threading it through the trapped nut makes for a bracing system to move the single nut on the top up and down to tighten it easily onto the rail, allowing for a tight fit.

description.text: None of the existing bandsaw inserts seem to fit, so made one and added a little thickness. Seems to work well with my older Rockwell 14". Including Fusion and step files so you can customize.

I've had this IKEA tea pot for a long time, but the lid disappeared ages ago. I've been using tea saucers as a lid, but now that I have a 3D printer, I decided to get off my lazy butt and make something specific.

This is just the middle part of the lid - the part that covers the diffuser (the white part in the photo). I've also included the OpenSCAD file in case you want to mess with the file and make your own lid of any size for another container. The scad file is set to draw cylinders with 256 sides and spheres with 512, so it takes a really long time to render. Lower those values to improve render times (at the expense of print quality if you don't change them back).

You should study the impact of the toxicity of different printing materials when in contact with hot liquid before printing this, if that sort of thing concerns you. In theory, PLA is going to leak some lactic acid, which is considered "generally safe." ABS probably gets pretty nasty at temperatures near water's boiling point. But I have an (possibly irrational) aversion to ingesting petroleum, so maybe it's nothing. Do your own research if you care.

UPDATE **
I have added several more variations to the bins. I also resaved everything in mm instead of inches as some of the slicers didn't autoscale the parts up. Dimensions remain the same as the drawing. The Fusion 360 file with all the bins is included if you want different shapes/sizes.

Notes:

Bed lift is an issue with the large flat bottom and straight walls. Prints fine with PLA but cannot get ABS to stay flat. Edge Needs supports or you end up with strings hanging off. I had to dial the overhang distance <4mm to get support under the small lip. In Simplify3d this was the under the "customized support structures" tool menu and needed to be done prior to generating the G-Code.

This was designed in Fusion 360 and I have included the archive file. The timeline is a bit of a mess but if you edit an individual component (bin) it is not too complex.

I was trying to get to a fully parametric design that I could just plug in the number of columns and rows and get a variety of bins. This didn't work out but the base sketch does have some formulas to divide the number of pattern divisions evenly. Several user parameters were set up with the idea that you could easily adjust the size of all the parts. I have not tested this, use at your own risk.

If anyone has ideas on how to do this better, let me know.

A creation I made in Structure Synth and my attempt to make it 3D printer friendly.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1

Structure Synth

Initially, I created the base file using a program called Structure Synth which I learned about from Angus from Maker's Muse. The code essentially created 100 cubes which were translated and rotated X, Y, Z amount per iteration and then rotated along an origin 100 times at a certain degree each time. I exported the result as a .obj file and loaded it up into Mesh Mixer.

Mesh Mixer

Initially, I thought to upload the file directly to Netfabb in order to fix all of the non-manifold objects, but I kept on getting error 103. I decided to load it up instead into Mesh Mixer where I made the object solid using precision instead of fast and then added a torus around the edges to make it more structurally stable. I then combined the torus and main body together and exported as an .stl.

Netfabb Online Services

Finally, to make sure there were no errors remaining, I uploaded to Netfabb and this time, the model was successfully processed and fixed. What I have here is the result.

title: Brushless beecheese frame (Semi ducted micro brushless frame)

description.text:
My first design for a brushless micro quadcopter.

So far it works quite well. :) I have done 3 flights since i got my lpf and notch settings done. Now it needs further PID tuning. It does fly with an old NAZE32 for the moment. Will be replaced with an F4 board with OSD soon. The DYS 1104 7000KV motors work great as soon as you found the right settings for your filters. Otherwise they will burn your frame. Or themselfes. The filters will be quite a bit off to the standart settings. Yaw axis was worst. I had to reduce gyro lpf on yaw to 60hz to get a clean gyro line. This may have to do with the vibrations coming from the frame itself. The motor had most vibration around 150Hz, so i set notch 1 to 120-160hz. Dynamic filtering may do a great job, but i cant test it on this old F1 board. Anyhow, it can take some hits. But for sure it is no tank.

I flew it using a 850mah 3S Lipo, wich might be a bit heavy for this setup. I would recommend around 600mah with at least 45C at 3S. The 2S felt a bit like a brushed copter. As you can see in the motors display of the posted video, they max out very often at even quite chilledflight style. I would not recommend it for acro. But for a bit of cruising around, its still fun even at only 2S. And motors come down quite cold.

When powering your quad from 3S, you can feel the power! Just check the motor temperatures.

It should fit a runcam split. I just dont have one to test it.

If you have some flexible filament you may print the tpu motor mounts to reduce vibrations on your frame. For me this worked quite good.
You may also try to print the short standoffs using tpu. I did not test it, but this should also reduce vibrations. For now i mounted my board onto slices of "oropax" earplugs. This works quite well.

I would be very happy to see your make and get some feedback :)

Update 01: I have added more rigid and better fitting standoffs.
Update 02: Added a adapter plate for 16x16mm and 20x20mm esc/fc boards.

First testflights:

title: X-end-motor Prusa i3 mk2s Fix for skewed x-axis

description.text:
Reworked the x-end-motor and idler part from Prusa to get rid of skewed x-axis. Originally the top smooth rod hole is 0.5mm deeper in the top than bottom, causing right hand side of x-axis to fall down during power cut off. Z-axis needed calibration/run it all the way up, after each power up, but with these new files that is not needed anymore. Seems like it is less strain on stepper motors as well. The fault is in Prusa's original files, so I needed to draw them up from scratch.

I redesigned the parts for PETG material which has less shrinkage, and for IGUS bearings. The IGUS bearings are held in place by a 0.2mm x 0.7mm lip inside the holder. Press it in while carefully expanding the gap at the same time with a screwdriver or similar.

Also I included the original design (files without PETG in name) for printing in ABS and with original linear bearings.

I recommend printing both the x-end-idler and x-end-motor parts when upgrading, as you then get the most accurate height on both sides of the x-axis with the same settings and material.

comments.text: They are the same dimensions, my «Igus version» may fit ordinary linear bearings as well, but I have not tested it. As for tension, the IGUS bearings are held firmly in place, I think more tension would deform them. If you are thinking about belt tensioning, I wanted to have these parts as close to original as possible and have not had any problems with belt becoming loose.
comments.author: JBFUK

comments.text: Thanks, my printer is not an original MK2 (it's custom built from long before the official i3 kit was available).  As I replace parts I'm trying to use as many original MK2(s) parts as possible.  Your comments on the miss-match and required re-calibration each print are interesting so I would like to use your design.
comments.author: Mikaelj

comments.text: I understand, yes, please do that :) The STEP files should be a good starting point. I had a hard time finding the original design in a proper editable format, and Prusa did not want to share the files in other than stl, so I had to remodel them in solidworks.
comments.author: JBFUK

comments.text: So I have read a bit more about the design and it looks like there is some level of tensioning capability in the motor position and bolts that act on the smooth rods.
comments.author: Mikaelj

comments.text: Yes, my part from Prusa was actually off by 0.8mm and made the top longer than bottom rod. When winding the threaded rods by hand on both sides, I could feel the resistance, and right hand side wanted to come down when there is no power to the stepper motors, ending up with a skewed axis that needed calibration.
comments.author: JBFUK

comments.text: I see, so it's not a problem with the original design just that one of your rods was a little too long.  You could have just shortened the rod rather than re-design the part?  As my rods are the same length I guess I'll be better off using the original parts.
comments.author: Mikaelj

comments.text: No, sorry for not being clear. The hole depths on Prusas original parts are off by 0.5mm. Making the top rod sticking out more than bottom one, even though the rods have the same length. I measured the STL files from prusa in SW, see images with measurements attached to this part.

description.text:
Just print in nylon - work perfect.
Remixed:
  • Up a little fan
  • Bigger hole in tensioner

A friend of mine asked if I could fix the head of her bike key with my 3d printer, so I decided to give it a try. I designed the new handle using Onshape after taking a picture of the key shaft and generated the gcode with Slic3r. Using an online gcode viewer I determined at which line of the code I should have placed the key shaft on the print to incorporate it in the new head and to avoid any collision with the hot-end. After this layer line, I added the following gcode:

G! X0 Y0
G4 S60

which moves the head of the printer to the bed XY origin and pauses everything for 60 seconds.
The printing process went exactly as expected, after roughly 2/3 of the printing time the hot-end moved away from the part, I added the key shaft to the part and after 60 seconds the printer started again with the remaining of the print. I am quite happy with the result which turned out to be surprisingly stiff and functional.

Links:

-Key head design:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/fd61572c7d3138b7e7b75b20/w/864ddd702f8c15d346fdc889/e/9213425f94ac74a4c7d51193

-gcode viewer: http://gcode.ws/

WARNING:
Be sure to know what you are doing when you modify the original gcode, since every command will be interpreted by the printer literally and this may cause damage to the machine or to people.

title: Anet A8 Heatbed Camera Mount Logitech C920

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2008595.
Excerpt from the original:

This make is for a bracket for mounting a camera to the hotbed of Anet A8 printers. The bracket affixes to the top of the H-bracket, below the actual hotbed. We re-use the holes for the linear bearings and an end clamp to attach the mount to the H-bracket. There are two versions of the bracket, one which attaches to either the back right (nearest power supply) or front left. The other version attaches to either the back left (nearest mainboard) or front right. Minimally one bracket needs to be installed. For each bracket you will need: 4x M4 12mm bolts (these will replace the M4 8mm bolts attaching the H-bracket to the bearing), 2x M3 10mm bolts, and 2x 10mm nuts (these attach the clamp). Please note, the clearance under the clamp and the overhang of the bracket is critical to prevent the attachment from crashing into the printer supports. Check clearance on installation and before each use. Damage to your printer is not my responsibility.

TL;DR Required hardware (all from spare parts that came with the Anet A8)
  • 4: M4 12mm screw
  • 2: M3 10mm screw
  • 2: M3 nuts
  • For each arm: M3 20mm screw & M3 nut

I found there wasn't enough clearance when a heavy webcam was attached so I made made more.

I also created a way to mount a Logitech C920 webcam such that it can be removed easily, but should hold on quite tight.

Currently I am using the mount in the back right of the heat bed and have had good success :).

title: Meraki MR18 Stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Stand for a Meraki MR18 WAP. Print this on its back.

I use this AP at home and and it's been sitting on my TV stand for 2 years since I don't plan on drilling holes into my apartment walls to mount it. Designed this quick, no fuss stand to make it look nicer sitting on a table by my TV.

Uses the existing mounting holes to slot into snugly and physics should do the rest to keep it upright. Might go back and extend the top mount point by 1mm to account for the slight curve on the back of the MR18, but works perfectly fine the way it is.

As a bonus, the right leg is right under the status light and if you print in white, you can see the reflected status color.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Variable (.35-.05)

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I use the variable detail levels in Slic3r to increase the detail on the flared mount point to make it smoother for a better fit. It's designed to be very snug. Also did the same for the filet on the base, but that was just so it looks nicer... not that anyone will see it once it's doing its job. Most of the other layers are printed at the lowest detail aside from some curves and things for purely aesthetic reason. This would probably print fine at .2 all the way, but I only printed one so I can't say for sure.

I did 5 of each the perimeters, top, and bottom layers along with the 50% infill to give it a good amount of strength. The MR18 is decently heavy and needs something strong. Might be able to get away with less on ABS prints.

This is a fan-made model of the famous iron helmet from the Bethesda video game: TES V: skyrim. We shaped the various details of the helm following the ones on the textures and on the normal maps in the game.

Please feel free to give us a tip in our public profile here on thingiverse, we would be grateful to you.

The helmet is shaped for a relatively large head, we invite you to follow this table to re-scale it according to your needs. (NOTE: These values ​​are only indicative, we invite you to take the measurements on yourself and scale it as needed).
94% = Small
97% = Medium
100% = Wide
103% = Extra Large

Have a good printing time!

Gli Artigiani di Avalon

HOW TO COLOR:

Just give a tick layer of Black plastic primer, then a Spray Chrome layer.
Leave it Dry.
Next day give a layer of dark metal spray. Once dryed, you can scratch the dark colour revealing the chrome from the previous layer.
If you wish, you can put some rust in little spot around the rivets or the eyes.

For the horns, use at least 3 different shades of sand.

We suggest you to darken areas were 2 or more part are close together, in order to recreate a sort of Ambient Occlusion (use dry brush technique or aribrush).

Final: Use a Clear Glossy transparent acrylic spray all over the helmet, leaving the horns matte.
Made this cover from this base: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:66197

This was created to replace the 9 blade "muffin" fan on my Anet A8 extruder. The stock fan is weak and unfortunately if you have the same problem I did and break a blade the fan becomes VERY noisy and vibrates excessively (affecting print quality). Since I have the printer and it seemed like a great challenge why not print my own blade rather than buying a whole new fan! A new fan costs approximately $6 to $12 plus shipping and possible wiring modifications, while this blade is just pennies to print with no shipping!

Disassembly is moderately easy and this will directly replace the broken blade. The end result is VERY quiet and extremely smooth running.

Disassembly and Re-assembly:

  1. Remove the fan from the extruder
  2. Remove the label on the back of the fan
  3. Remove the "Small" plastic snap ring that hold the original fan blade in place
  4. Pop out the old broken blade
  5. using a small screwdriver gently pry up the magnetic ring inside the old blade. Be aware there is a metal ring around the magnetic ring. Be careful to NOT damage the magnetic ring. It is VERY SOFT. You will need BOTH parts.
  6. Press the magnetic and metal ring with the same orientation into the new blade.
  7. Pull the center pin out of the old blade. Pay attention to the orientation. There is a ringed end for the c-clip and a "Crimped" end that goes into the plastic.
  8. Insert the pin into the new blade with the correct orientation. You may need to use a drop of super glue or what I did was heat the pin end with a lighter and slip it into the center hole of the new blade. You may even need to do BOTH just to make sure the pin stays in. Make sure the pin is strait up and down.
  9. Test fit the fan and make sure it spins freely. You can power up the system to make sure it works if you need to. You can use a little 3-in-1 oil or as I did, Hoppe's Gun Oil
  10. replace the c-clip snap ring on the back of the fan body and re-install the extruder fan.

Your done and will hopefully have an efficient smooth running and quiet extruder fan!! If the fan sticks initially you can spin it by hand while powered up and see if it frees up. there may be a little glue on the pin or a burr from the pliers.

title: Filastruder Active Carbon and Hepa Filter Mount

description.text:
Update 10/29/17 V2: Shortened the barrel on the top so it doesn't creep past the insulation and added a bracket on the inside of the mount to keep the mount from tilting under the weight of the filter.

This is an adapter to mount the Active Carbon and Hepa Filter assembly set by Donzi ( https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764408 ) for the Filastruder.

The 60 mm fan for filament cooling is mostly unused in the configuration it's shipped for, leaving plenty of extra air flow to be used for air filtering and cooling! The fan doesn't pull a lot of air in this configuration, but it seems to work well for stripping any smell from the filament extrusion process and cool the filament at the same time.

You'll want to print the 60 mm adapter and the half inch body for the active carbon portion of the filter.

I purchased these parts to use with the filter, you'll need the small HEPA filters and some disposable active carbon:
1) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01I2QUCOM/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1
2) https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0002566WY/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o07_s01?ie=UTF8&psc=1

You'll also need some metal mesh from your local hardware store to help hold in the active carbon.

Printer:

D-bot

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%+

Notes:

It would be wise to print this in ABS, if you find the filament touching the perimeter of the exit circle just push the filter up a bit. If you get the plastic too close to the nozzle though you'll risk overheating it. There's enough tolerance that finding the right balance shouldn't take you more than a few seconds.

Once printed zip tie the mount to the insulation on the filastruder barrel and then zip tie the filter assembly to the mount. You may have to link multiple zip ties together to get around the mount and filter assembly, but that shouldn't cause any issues. Be sure to ensure air flow is pulling air through the filter assembly, not pushing it into it. You should also make sure that the fan is not obstructed by any objects so that you get a reasonable air flow.

title: Bosch COLT Palm Router Wedge For DYI Acoustic Guitar Building

description.text: This is a set of 1.5 degree and 5 degree wedge for Bosch COLT Palm Router PR10E that will be necessary when you build an acoustic guitar. Guitar top is about 1.5 degree arched and the back is 5 degree arch. So if you use a router with the flat base plate that comes with the router to trim the overhangs or carving the side/top for binding/purflings of top or back, you will end up with trimming more woods than you are supposed to do. With these router wedges attached to the Bosch PR10E, you will be able to trim/curve guitar body safely and easily. I have made two guitar kits from StewMac (Stewart MacDonald) with these wedges and confirmed it works great.

description.text:
My first experiences with 3D printing were pretty frustrating, largely due to difficulties in getting and keeping the Z index properly adjusted. I hope this helps some people avoid some of the problems I experienced. And for those who are beyond the beginning part of your 3D printing experience, this should help make a common task easier.

When I first got my RepRap Guru (Prusa clone) printer, it shipped with a few design flaws in the Z stop mechanism. I'm guessing mine's not the only one. The good news is that the thing with design flaws has a way of making things to fix its design flaws. So, here we go...

Problem 1: The way to adjust the Z index stop was to move the bracket that holds the switch. This turned out to be very tedious, and I ended up breaking the bracket that came with the printer by handling it too much (specifically, by tightening it down too much - see below). A moving index stop switch is not terribly useful.

Problem 2: The switch could only be mounted to its bracket by one bolt, meaning it could turn freely unless I tightened it down REALLY hard. Again with the moving switch!

Problem 3: The bracket was taller than the switch, so if the switch wasn't rotated in the bracket properly, the switch would never trigger and the print head would keep moving downward, pushing the entire bracket and switch with it. On more than one occasion, I have had to franticly pull the power from the printer to stop the print head from pressing further into the bed. Ouch! (I later realized that I could just manually activate the switch with a finger, but when I was new and didn't know the equipment, I freaked out, OK?)

Problem 4: The default stopping mechanism was to allow the X axis carriage (the one that moves up and down on the Z axis) to "crash" into the switch, and unless the switch was tightened down to the printer VERY hard, it would move out of place. Yep, another "moving switch" scenario.

The solution started with this thing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1175592
This resolves problems 1 and 4. However, instead of using it how they picture, I super glued a nut to the top of the piece, screwed the bolt in upside-down (from the bottom-up) and added a spring to the underside of the bolt to keep downward pressure on it (see picture) and keep it from vibrating out of place. This has worked very, very well for me.

Part 2 of the solution is this thing. It adds a shelf underneath the switch for support, gives enough space to use two bolts to secure the switch to the bracket and prevent it from rotating (the support shelf also reinforces that), and keeps the mechanical arm 100% above the bracket so you can't possibly "not trigger" the switch.

This should work for any standard RAMPS 1.4 index stop switch. This will probably also work as X and Y index stop brackets, but since those don't have to be nearly as precise, I haven't felt compelled to make improvements to them.

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

No

Notes:

You shouldn't need rafts or supports, and infill is probably irrelevant as long as you have it 10% or above. I printed at 40%, and it printed and works perfectly.

You should be able to attach this to your printer in exactly the same way as the current bracket.

You will need an M4 bolt and nut to connect the bracket to the printer (typically connected to an X axis motor carriage guide) and two M3 bolts and nuts to connect the switch to the bracket. These nuts and bolts are probably already connected to the current Z index stop bracket, so use those if you've got 'em.
Made at blockscad3d.com

I've included the OpenSCAD file in case anyone is interested in making changes for other printers. This was one of my first projects in scad, so the measurements are hard-coded instead of being variables. Sorry. If I find a compelling reason to make a version 2 of this thing, I'll fix that.

title: MKS TFT28 and Arduino Mega 2560 (CH340G) Fix

description.text: Some time ago I solved problem with serial communication of the external display module MKS TFT28 with the Chinese clone Arduino Mega 2560 (on RAMPS connector AUX-1). After thoroughly analyzing circuit with the CH340G (USB UART), I found the cause of this problem. It's a bad application the CH340G on the Arduino board. Modification requires removal of resistors R10, R11 and replace R12, R13 (680Ω). The only minor cosmetic deficiency of this modification is the disfunction of the RX and TX LEDs, which, of course, has no negative effect on the functionality of serial communication with the Arduino.

comments.text: I wish I discovered this yesterday. I came to the conclusion that the CH340G was to blame, the boards with the atmel chips worked fine. This is some fine investigation work you did here.

title: X-Carve with Dewalt 611 Spindle - JTech Side Laser Mount

description.text:
This is a custom laser cutter/engraver mount for the Dewalt Spindle Holder in the X-Carve CNC Machine.

The laser head is built by JTechPhotonics. I use the 3.8 watt Version, but any head should fit (as of Sept/2017).

This will mount your laser to the left side of the spindle mount to allow for dust shoe. The reason for the extended distance is to clear the dust shoe side mounts.

I used slots instead of holes to allow for the head to be moved up/down for fine tuning the distance. In my case it was mounted at 2.5" from the work surface with enough clearance distance from the work area to the collet. The beam focused perfectly within the factory recommended distance (1" to 3").

The back aperture (hole) is to let the laser cables go thru it and be more organized.

author: Chalk

description.text:
Recently I went to print a model the was 171mm tall and unfortunately I never thought I'd want to print that tall when building the hypercube, But I spotted something that Tech2c missed (maybe). If you raise the top 2020 extrusion up above the vertical extrusions and remove the 20mm internal corner brackets you gain an extra 40mm of space and a potential 40mm of extra build height.
Here is where I ran into the next issue, attaching the corner brackets only allows for half of the gained space due to the XY joiner as the 10mm aluminium tube runs right below the top length of extrusion, I'm currently redesigning the XY joiners to allow the tube to run inside the frame and I'll release the files as soon as I know they work.

For now, I give you a free 20mm of build height!

There are two options (who does't love options) the first replaces all of the corner brackets and the second replaces two and you use a metal corner bracket on the top inside section between the X and Y extrusions.

Installation:
Unbolt the top of the frame and move the XY assembly up 20mm, the 20mm metal corner brackets can be used as reference. Place the corner raisers on the Z 2020 extrusion and tighten them in place. Then bolt the X and Y extrusions in.

Hypercube

If your bridging is good enough don't bother with supports

description.text:
A firewall for the standard size Flitetest power pod (for Spitfire, Mustang, Simple Cub, etc).

It has side walls so it gives the power pod more strength (the holes give the hot-glue extra grip).

You don't need supports if you have a part-cooling fan (PLA).

I used 0.2mm resolution, 4 top layers, 4 bottom layers, 5 shells, 15% infill and it weighs 9 grams.

This is a 40HP Eurorack panel for mounting Korg Volca synthesizers directly into a Eurorack system.

Remove the Volca case from the PCB, desolder the battery and speaker cables and use 4 of the original screws to attach the Volca PCB to this Eurorack panel.

You need a 9V power supply to power the Volcas. You can either use a wall adapter or you can create a simple 12V to 9V linear regulator on a small perfboard to directly power the Volcas from your Eurorack power bus (In my case i also added a simple amplifier to boost the Volca audio output to the Eurorack audio level).

title: Tika Alpaca (movable legs!)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A friendly pack animal to carry you through the day. With two pairs of movable legs and a spirit for adventure, this alpaca will surely brighten your life.
Alpacas get lonely. So why not print in pairs?
Get a special edition traveler alpaca, complete with saddle bags, by becoming our patron!

Designed as an aesthetic, multi-functional test and calibration model, this alpaca works great for testing your printer's bridging, overhang, supports, and bed adhesion capability as shown here.

If you like this smooth, clean look, you might like Grumbo, our solid, blocky elephant.

Note
Make sure you give your new best friend enough infill, otherwise the tail might detach.
You can print this alpaca down to 60% of provided size (baby alpacas!!!) if your printer can work with a bridge of clearance 0.3mm. The original has 0.5mm clearance.
Inspiration from: LeFabshop Elephant

Do you want a discount to print this on 3D Hubs? Here you go: http://3dhubs.refr.cc/5D323XS
How about discounted filament? http://r.sloyalty.com/r/vowQk944fAdh
See apps, projects, and other designs we make at tika.io

comments.text:
One other person has reported this issue as well, but I have never seemed to be able to fix the problem of the tail sometimes detaching. I have opened and inspected the file in Meshmixer multiple times (I don't have Simplify3D) and no issues could be found.
About 30% of the ones I print detach as well, but I think it might just be a combination of the diameter and angle of a specific part of the tail that makes it prone to detaching.
I've refixed and reuploaded a new version of the alpaca (you'll get it when you download above) just for good measure, but I might try tweaking the design of the tail so that it'll stay on better.

print_settings.Notes:: Print this as it appears in the STL. When it's finished, scrape the top smooth with a knife. The smooth side that was in contact with the bed is the side that you present to the dial indicator.

title: i3 Z axis dial indicator calibration post

description.text:
I've seen people levelling their Z axis by measuring from the bed, but this doesn't seem like a good idea, seeing as the bed is a moveable object. I think it's smarter to level the Z axis by measuring from the frame.

This simple object is a post that fits into the space between the bed and the towers. You hang a dial indicator from the X axis rods and put this post underneath it. Measure the height under the X stepper motor side, then go to the idler side and make it match up.

Notes:

Print this as it appears in the STL. When it's finished, scrape the top smooth with a knife. The smooth side that was in contact with the bed is the side that you present to the dial indicator.

author: Asvin88

description.text:
Remote control glider aerotow is great fun and can be done with a variety of gliders and tow planes. To do it safely it is important to have a reliable and easy to use release mechanism on both the glider and tow plane.

This tow release mechanism is designed for remote control gliders in the 1m-3m wingspan size range. It is designed specifically to work in foam or balsa gliders and tow planes that need the tow point mounted in the top or bottom of the fuselage. By mounting the tow release mechanism in the underside of the glider it allows a motor glider to be towed without having to remove the motor or make any changes to the nose cone. As long as you make sure the motor can't come on while you are being towed, you don't even have to remove the prop.

Required hardware

  • 1x 9g - 12g standard micro servo (works great with HS55 or HXT900 servos)
  • 2x short lengths of steel wire 1-2mm diameter
  • 1x M3x12mm machine screw

Supports
The main body of the tow release will require some support material for both the recess for the flange, and the slot that the pivot arm fits into. The pivot arm can be printed without support if printed on it's side, but will require some support if printed flat.

Assembly
Before assembling the mechanism you will need to drill out the holes for the steel wire in both the main body and the pivot arm. These holes have been intentionally designed under sized, so you can drill them to suit your choice of wire.
I have used both 1mm and 2mm and both work well, so any wire in that range should be fine.

Flange types
There are 3 different types of flanges that you can choose to suit your plane.

  • Type 1 has a wide flat flange to spread the load or allow the tow release to be installed in an existing hole.
  • Type 2 is curved to follow the curve of a glider fuselage.
  • Type 3 is a small flat flange to suit flat external surfaces.

The flanges are designed to be extra long so you can cut them to length to fit your plane, or you can adjust you slicer settings to stop printing at the right height.

Tow line
I use these tow release mechanisms with a tow line made from "builders" sting line with a small loop of thick fishing line tied on at each end. The fishing line makes for an easy to insert loop, that reliably comes free without snagging on release. From my experience with gliders in the 1.5m-3m size range a tow line about 12-16m long works well.

author: dioxik

print_settings.Notes:: I suggest 30% infill or higher and use 3 or 4 shell walls to assure that no suction is being lost through the walls. Even though my spindle is 80mm, I had to set the diameter in the scad file to 80.5mm for a better fit. You might also need to add 0.5mm. Very useful comments are in the scad file so that you can adjust an produce your own STL file for printing. I've made this in PETG and PLA with no issues, I'm sure it works with ABS as well.

title: Better Dust Shoe for Round Spindle CNC's

description.text:
https://youtu.be/DHb6F92jSfw
This is a single part CNC dust shoe that directs the suction toward a small area around the bit, unlike most devices for this purpose. The scad file allows one to adjust parameters to match any CNC and vacuum hose as long as the CNC motor is perfectly round. If the motor is not a perfect cylinder shape, the design might still work, but you'd have to find a radius that allows good grip. I include an STL file which works for the Axiom Pro series CNC machines (80mm spindle), but you might still have to adjust for your vac hose even if you have an Axiom. The design in the STL file is for the Stanley 6 HP 8 Gallon Stainless Steel Vacuum which is at Wal-Mart for 55$ USD.

This design also uses less plastic and is still easy to slip on and off. Furthermore, the scad code is open source and you can adjust many parameters easily in the beginning of the .scad file.

The design easily attaches to the spindle by sliding on and using a paper clip to clamp onto the motor. The hole for the hose pipe is tapered (radius 1mm too big on top, 1mm too small on bottom), so you can slide a regular PVC pipe to attach a soft hose if necessary. I just slide my cheap Stanley vac hose directly into the tapered hole and it seals perfectly.

print_settings.Notes:: You need a printer of roughly 8 x 7 x 6 meter. Print between 40 and 100 mm/s. 50 mm nozzle with double height wings.

description.text:
This project was initiated in the spring of 2017 with the goal to show how you can possibly 3D print a fully functional and certified building according the Danish and European standards (some of the toughest standards in the world).

In september '17 we printed the foundation rim. You can follow the project here:

https://3dprinthuset.dk/europes-first-3d-printed-building/

Printer:

Concrete 6770

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

20mm

Infill:

none

Notes:

You need a printer of roughly 8 x 7 x 6 meter. Print between 40 and 100 mm/s. 50 mm nozzle with double height wings.

Before printing
  • Secure a building site
  • Secure a building permit
  • Make foundation according to local building code. The house is roughly 200 KN
  • Make sure the the printer is as level to the print foundation as possible
First layer

The first layer should be a "levelling" layer as slab foundations are not typically level to mm precision.

  • Run one dry (no material) layer approx. 5-10 mm from ground surface and make sure the nozzle does not hit the ground.
  • Run the same layer again with 150% extrusion.
  • Set the current height (g92 z...)
After print
  • Insert windows, doors, electricity and roof.
  • Can be finished with paint or similar.

Architect: Ana Goidea

The architecture of the building shows that the application of 3D printing technologies frees the formal expression of the design. This implies that organic curvatures and textures can be easily achieved, bringing the mass customization strategies into the architectural scale. And the benefits of the technology are not only visual: integration of multiple functionalities into complex geometries is now possible and without the cost penalty and difficulties of tight tolerances in manual labor.

comments.text:
I printed at 0.15mm with a 0.4mm nozzle and found that many of the parts were too thin. My slicer was thus not printing the bottom most layer of the models or the thin parts.
The sword cross-guard had difficulty due to the thickness, and wooden shields did not print well because the slicer had trouble identifying the first layer.
This would suggest to me that the models need to be extruded down about 0.2mm to 0.4mm to give them a thicker base for greater than 0.1mm layer heights. It may also be necessary to use a different sword for the design or increase the size by a scale factor of 1.2.
comments.author: Haratu

comments.text: You will very likely need to print these at .1mm resolution to get all the parts to print.  I did notice that the wood shield on Male B did not print the area between the boards.  I ended up liking the look better, like the shield was old and worn, so I left it that way.

title: OpenForge Cut-Stone OpenLOCK Floors - Top Locks
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OpenForge magnet tiles require printing a bottom and a top half, then gluing together. With the high cost of magnets and printing tons and tons of bases, it becomes expensive to have all the different floor styles on hand that you might want.

Inspired by the modularity of the OpenLOCK movement, here is a simple clip that prints on top of the OpenForge base and a corresponding slot in the Openforge floor tiles so you can slide them out and swap out floor styles at will, without needing a separate set of magnet bases. Simply set the top slot over the clips in the base and slide diagonally into place!

I'd like to hear some feedback if this is an idea people could make use of! So far I have only made the Cut-Stone version, but I am planning on making more as needed and have also included the clip and slots which can be placed and booleaned together with existing pieces.

Edit - 12/4/2017: Added in some support under the locking pins in the base, fixing the fragility problem noted by nightpanda2810.

title: Robo3D R1 R1+ Extruder Camera (Pi Zero W)

description.text:
Purpose: Provide an extruder-mounted camera to better-view the crucial first layer and to follow the print upwards in case you have very high prints

Parts you will need:

  • This thing (of course)
  • 1x Pi Zero W
  • 1x Raspberry Pi Camera Module
  • 1x Pi Raspberry Pi Zero v1.3 Camera Cable http://www.adafruit.com/product/3157 (converts to smaller pin pitch)
  • 2x standard 608ZZ bearings
  • Hot Glue for assembly
  • Wires for 5V line (stranded preferably but solid works too)

Printing Recommendations
I suggest you print the Pi Zero Backplate with the bearing mounts in the vertical position for pin strength. The overhang shouldn't be too much on the top. Mattercontrol didn't feel it needed any.

  • Retainer bar can be low res, like 0.3
  • The rest should be fine at 0.2 with 20-30% infill

Assembly Instructions

  • Put all the parts together as shown in the assembled stl file
  • Fasten them all together with hot glue
  • Put a strip of hot glue on both side of the pi enclosure assembly to lock-in the mount that goes onto the extruder. Just enough to make sure it doesn't wobble at the end of it's bearing "track"
  • Use whatever software you can find to capture or stream the video from the pi cam. I suggest mjpg_streamer or the builtin rasipvid util and some program capable of streaming, like VLC.

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Yes

Yes

0.2-0.3

20-30%

This is a simple part-cooling fan bracket for the Renkforce RF100. It holds a 50mm fan and directs the air to the sides of the nozzle.

The fan is a 12V fan and is powered from the same feed as the extruder cooler.

!! Please be aware that to much cooling can negatively impact the adhesion of the first layer to the print bed. It would be a good idea to insert a switch in the fan power feed to disable the fan while printing the first layer. (As the RF100 was not designed to use a part-cooling fan there is no output on the controller board to connect and control it easily). !!

In my case i have a little PWM controller and a switch in the feed so i can control when and how fast the fan is spinning.

The fan holder is printed as one piece and is attached using the front mounting screw used for the extruder cover.

Best way to print it is to place the side with the round hole (where the fan mounts) flat on the bed. The overhangs etc. should print OK; The part was printed without supports on a Renkforce RF100 before installing it).

Printer:

Renkforce RF100
